text: In this video we're going to have a look at the delay device and walk through its various features.
Delay is a versatile device that combines many useful features into an accessible interface.
The dry-wet parameter sets the balance between the original dry signal and the delayed wet signal.
The feedback parameter dials in how much of the device's output is fed back into the device's input.
This is what causes the repeats that we often associate with delay effects.
This parameter can reach a maximum of 95%.
Clicking on the delay sync button will toggle the repeated audio between tempo synced 16th notes and millisecond values.
Disabling the link button allows us to choose different delay times in the left and right channels.
This freeze button will endlessly repeat the sound that is currently stored in the effects buffer,
and will ignore any input signal until the button is deactivated again.
The filter section allows us to sculpt the sound of the repeats by filtering out the higher and lower frequencies.
The modulation section underneath allows further creative control over the repeats generated by the device.
We can dial in the speed of the modulation and apply individually to both the position of the filter or the speed of the repeats.
The mode section allows us to decide how changes in delay time will be processed.
The delay time is set to 0.
Fade crossfades between new and old delay times.
Selecting jump means that the delay time values suddenly update when the delay time is changed,
almost as if the delay times jump from one value to the other.
Finally, with ping pong enabled, the delay lines will alternate between the left and right output channels.
If you have older projects that include either the simple delay or ping pong delay devices,
these will be automatically converted to delay when you open your project in Live 10.1.
